p: Félix Belzunce obtained a PhD (1996) in Mathematics from University of Murcia. He is a full Professor of Statistics at University of Murcia (SPAIN). His main research interests are nonparametric classification, ordering and dependence of distributions with applications in reliability, survival, risks, economics, stochastic processes, and reliability and survival nonparametric inference. He has published several papers on nonparametric classification, ordering, dependence, and nonparametric inference. He is Associate Editor for Communications in Statistics.

p: Eva-María Ortega graduated obtaining the Award of Degree with special distinction in Mathematics, and received an MS, and a PhD in Mathematics, both from University of Murcia in Spain. Her research focuses on stochastic orderings, aging notions, and dependence with applications in risk theory, reliability, and survival. Some other of her research interests lie in the areas of financial insurance portfolio modeling, and applied operational research. Currently, she is leading a research project at the Centro de Investigación Operativa (CIO) at the University Miguel Hernandez in Spain, and is an Associate Professor at Department of Statistics, Mathematics, and Computer Science at this university.

p: José M. Ruiz obtained a PhD (1979) in Mathematics at Universidad de Murcia, and was appointed a full Professor (1988) there. His research interests are characterization of distributions; classification and ordering of distributions with applications in reliability, survival, and economics; and reliability and survival nonparametric inference. He has supervised 11 PhD theses, and has published several papers on characterization, classification, and ordering; and reliability and survival nonparametric inference.

details.abstract: We introduce a failure and repair model that is a discrete-time version of the pure birth shock model. Its discrete lifetime is a random sum with support on N, and with geometric summands, that represent the number of successful tasks between consecutive shocks performed by an engineering system. We provide distributional properties and conditions that lead to the discrete aging properties of such random sums. Our results provide qualitative insight into the discrete lifetime distribution of our model.

context.text: The pure birth shock model arises naturally when a system is subjected to shocks which occur randomly in time according to a Markov process, such that given \$k\$ shocks have occurred in \$(0,t]\$, the probability of a shock in \$(t,t+\Delta t]\$ is \$\lambda_{k}\Delta t+o(\Delta t)\$; while the probability of more than one shock in \$(t,t+\Delta t]\$ is \$o(\Delta t)\$, where \$\lim_{\Delta t\rightarrow 0}(o(\Delta t)/\Delta t)=0\$ (see A-Hameed & Proschan [23]).

Under suitable conditions on the parameters \$\lambda_{k}\$, and \$\overline{P}_{k}\$, \$k=0,1,\ldots\$, some aging properties for the pure birth shock model have been studied by A-Hameed & Proschan [23], Klefsjö [24], [25], Pérez-Ocón & Gámiz-Pérez [26], and Belzunce & Ortega & Ruiz [12].

Several open questions are posed in section four.
